clinical_study.brief_title: Does Continued Use of Clopidogrel Into Surgery Cause Increased Perioperative Bleeding?
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Clopidogrel Use in Peri-Operative General Surgery Patients: A Prospective Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

clinical_study.source: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock: Patients who on taking clopidogrel are randomized to either continue clopidogrel into general surgery or discontinue clopidogrel 7 days before surgery. All patients resume clopidogrel after surgery. The investigators track the development of bleeding complications that may develop within 90 days of the surgery. Patients are medically cleared to be in either arm of the study by their cardiologist and surgeon. There is currently no evidence to support for or against the use continuation or discontinuation of clopidogrel prior to general surgery.

primary_outcome.description: Development of perioperative bleeding complications, including need for blood transfusions, hematoma, and bleeding requiring re-admission or re-operation

secondary_outcome.measure: Development of myocardial infarction or thrombosis

arm_group.description: Continue home dose of clopidogrel into surgery
Discontinue home dose of clopidogrel one week before surgery. Resume after surgery.

intervention.description: Continue home dose of clopidogrel into surgery
Discontinue home dose of clopidogrel one week before surgery. Resume after surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- taking clopidogrel
- undergoing general surgery
- cleared by both cardiologist and surgery for randomized arm
Exclusion Criteria:
- previous history of bleeding complications/bleeding disposition
- no capacity to consent
